hints.label: def-yang-mills-qsd-fractal
hints.title: Yang-Mills QSD on Fractal Set
hints.content:
3408: :label: def-yang-mills-qsd-fractal
3409: 
3410: On the Fractal Set lattice $\Lambda_{\text{fractal}}$, the Yang-Mills quantum canonical ensemble is:
3411: 
3412: $$
3413: \hat{\rho}_{\text{YM}} = \frac{1}{Z} \exp\left(-\beta \hat{H}_{\text{YM}}\right)
3414: $$
3415: 
3416: where:
3417: 
3418: $$
3419: \hat{H}_{\text{YM}} = \sum_{p \in \Lambda_{\text{fractal}}} \text{Tr}(F_{\mu\nu}(p) F^{\mu\nu}(p)) + \sum_{\ell \in \Lambda_{\text{fractal}}} m^2 \text{Tr}(A_\mu(\ell) A^\mu(\ell))
3420: $$
3421: 
3422: is the lattice Yang-Mills Hamiltonian with dynamical mass $m$ (Chapter 13, Theorem 13.5.1).

hints.label: thm-quantum-ruppeiner-yang-mills
hints.title: Quantum Ruppeiner Metric for Yang-Mills
hints.content:
3428: :label: thm-quantum-ruppeiner-yang-mills
3429: 
3430: The Ruppeiner metric on the Yang-Mills QSD manifold exhibits temperature-dependent behavior controlled by the **mass gap** $\Delta_{\text{YM}}$:
3431: 
3432: $$
3433: g_R^{\beta\beta} = \text{Var}(\hat{H}_{\text{YM}}) \sim \Delta_{\text{YM}}^2 \cdot e^{-\beta \Delta_{\text{YM}}}
3434: $$
3435: 
3436: **Regime analysis**:
3437: - **Low temperature** ($\beta \Delta_{\text{YM}} \gg 1$): Exponential suppression $e^{-\beta\Delta} \to 0$
3438: - **Critical regime** ($\beta \Delta_{\text{YM}} \sim O(1)$): Maximum curvature $\sim \Delta_{\text{YM}}^2$
3439: - **High temperature** ($\beta \Delta_{\text{YM}} \ll 1$): Classical limit $\sim \Delta_{\text{YM}}^2 (1 - \beta \Delta_{\text{YM}})$
3440: 
3441: **Physical meaning**: The Ruppeiner curvature peaks at $\beta \sim 1/\Delta_{\text{YM}}$ (i.e., $T \sim \Delta_{\text{YM}}/k_B$), providing a thermodynamic signature of the mass gap.

3427: :::{prf:theorem} Quantum Ruppeiner Metric for Yang-Mills
3428: :label: thm-quantum-ruppeiner-yang-mills
3429: 
3430: The Ruppeiner metric on the Yang-Mills QSD manifold exhibits temperature-dependent behavior controlled by the **mass gap** $\Delta_{\text{YM}}$:
3431: 
3432: $$
3433: g_R^{\beta\beta} = \text{Var}(\hat{H}_{\text{YM}}) \sim \Delta_{\text{YM}}^2 \cdot e^{-\beta \Delta_{\text{YM}}}
3434: $$
3435: 
3436: **Regime analysis**:
3437: - **Low temperature** ($\beta \Delta_{\text{YM}} \gg 1$): Exponential suppression $e^{-\beta\Delta} \to 0$
3438: - **Critical regime** ($\beta \Delta_{\text{YM}} \sim O(1)$): Maximum curvature $\sim \Delta_{\text{YM}}^2$
3439: - **High temperature** ($\beta \Delta_{\text{YM}} \ll 1$): Classical limit $\sim \Delta_{\text{YM}}^2 (1 - \beta \Delta_{\text{YM}})$
3440: 
3441: **Physical meaning**: The Ruppeiner curvature peaks at $\beta \sim 1/\Delta_{\text{YM}}$ (i.e., $T \sim \Delta_{\text{YM}}/k_B$), providing a thermodynamic signature of the mass gap.

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-42
hints.content:
3446: :::{prf:proof}
3447: 
3448: **Step 1**: Variance and spectral gap.
3449: 
3450: The variance of the Hamiltonian is:
3451: 
3452: $$
3453: \text{Var}(\hat{H}_{\text{YM}}) = \sum_n p_n (E_n - \langle E \rangle)^2
3454: $$
3455: 
3456: where $p_n = e^{-\beta E_n} / Z$ are the Boltzmann weights for energy levels $E_n$.
3457: 
3458: **Step 2**: Mass gap dominance.
3459: 
3460: At low temperature $\beta \gg 1$, the dominant contribution comes from the ground state $E_0$ and first excited state $E_1$:
3461: 
3462: $$
3463: \text{Var}(\hat{H}) \approx (E_1 - E_0)^2 \cdot \frac{e^{-\beta E_0} e^{-\beta E_1}}{Z^2} \sim \Delta_{\text{YM}}^2 \cdot e^{-\beta \Delta_{\text{YM}}}
3464: $$
3465: 
3466: where $\Delta_{\text{YM}} = E_1 - E_0$ is the mass gap.
3467: 
3468: **Step 3**: Ruppeiner metric and mass gap dependence.
3469: 
3470: $$
3471: g_R^{\beta\beta} = \text{Var}(\hat{H}) \sim \Delta_{\text{YM}}^2 e^{-\beta \Delta_{\text{YM}}}
3472: $$
3473: 
3474: **Regime analysis**:
3475: 
3476: 1. **Low temperature** ($\beta \Delta_{\text{YM}} \gg 1$): System frozen in ground state, variance exponentially suppressed
3477: 2. **Critical regime** ($\beta \Delta_{\text{YM}} \sim O(1)$): Exponential factor $e^{-O(1)} \sim O(1)$, giving maximum curvature $\sim \Delta_{\text{YM}}^2$
3478: 3. **High temperature** ($\beta \Delta_{\text{YM}} \ll 1$): Expand $e^{-x} \approx 1 - x$, giving $\text{Var}(\hat{H}) \sim \Delta_{\text{YM}}^2(1 - \beta \Delta_{\text{YM}})$
3479: 
3480: **Physical interpretation**: The Ruppeiner curvature **peaks** at $\beta \sim 1/\Delta_{\text{YM}}$ (i.e., $T \sim \Delta_{\text{YM}}/k_B$), where thermal fluctuations are maximally sensitive to the spectral gap. This provides a thermodynamic fingerprint of the mass gap.

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-81
hints.title: Computational Strategy
hints.content:
3486: :class: tip
3487: 
3488: **Algorithmic construction**:
3489: 1. Run the Fragile Gas on gauge field configuration space (Chapter 13, Algorithm 13.6.1)
3490: 2. Collect QSD samples $\{\{A_\mu^{(k)}\}\}_{k=1}^N$ (gauge field configurations)
3491: 3. Compute quantum observables: $\langle \hat{H} \rangle$, $\langle \hat{H}^2 \rangle$ via path integral Monte Carlo
3492: 4. Estimate $g_R^{\beta\beta} = \langle \hat{H}^2 \rangle - \langle \hat{H} \rangle^2$ (variance)
3493: 5. Monitor curvature to detect confinement-deconfinement transition
